comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: "Prince Nicholas Engalitcheff (ru: Николай Енгалычев, 1874–1935) was member of Russian nobility and later the Imperial Russian Vice Consul to Chicago during the early 1900s." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicholas_Engalitcheff See notes under He is probably pictured with his lawyers during the divorce trial. The New York Daily Telegram's account of the proceedings on 12/23/1915 indentifies his lawyer as Edward Willcox. The New York Herald's coverage on 12/25/1915 names James W. Osborne as his lawyer. fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin... fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... The men in the photo are likely Osborne and Edwin W. Willcox, who were later partners in the New York law firm of Osborne, Lamb & Willcox, listed in the Polk Directory for 1918-19. James Walker Osborne (1-8-1859 - 9-7-1919) was a famous trial lawyer who had before this time been a prosecutor and assitant district attorny for about 15 years. His New York Times obituary: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40610FF3E5E157A9...
